awd_titl_txt: Changing Mindsets to Promote Women & Girls in Science: Facilitating Participation of International Women in Science and Engineering
awd_abstract_narration: This project supports an international symposium to promote the participation of women and girls in science, including participants from countries that do not have significant collaborative activities with the US, developing countries in Africa and the Middle East, as well as countries that seek to advance women's roles in STEM research.  Participants will gain skills, establish virtual networks, and bring back knowledge to their communities that will in turn increase future collaborative opportunities for US scientists.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The Committee on Women in Science, Engineering and Medicine (CWSEM) in collaboration with the Policy and Global Affairs Division of the National
Research Council organized the participation of fifteen women scientists and
engineers from Africa and the Middle East in the 2011 US State Department's Changing Mindsets to Promote Women and Girls in Science Conference held in Washington, DC. CWSEM's responsibility included the provision of the logistical support to the women scientists and engineers as well as encouragement of their development as a cohort of women scientists that could become a support network for each other beyond the 2011 conference and training activities.

Taking full advantage of the talent and ability of all men and women is a critical component in addressing the global challenges that currently confront all societies.  The US State Department conference Changing Mindsets to Promote Women and Girls in Science was structured to focus on topics that are relevant to all scientific and engineering disciplines and it was envisioned as a catalyst in encouraging greater collaboration among US federal agencies and non-profit organizations on their global efforts for girls and women in science, engineering, and medicine.

Participants had an opportunity to learn about:

  • Cutting edge practices that are helping to attract girls to science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and support women in STEM, both in the US and internationally;
  • Ways in which societies can help empower women and girls through STEM;
  • How institutions in the developing world are working to overcome barriers to involvement in STEM, and how this makes a difference in the lives of women and girls; and
  • How the US government is helping women and girls in the developing world engage in STEM.

The women scientists and engineers also participated in a training program at the Fogarty International Center of the US National Institutes of Health (NIH).  This program focused on skills that facilitate career progression in science and engineering and included sessions on mentoring, networking, and grant writing. In addition to the events at the US State Department and NIH, CWSEM organized a welcome event during the participants' time in Washington, DC in order to facilitate collegiality within the cohort and to begin the process of creating a sense of community for these participants.

Theinternational participants for the Changing Mindsets to Promote Women and Girls in Science project included:

  • Judith S. Satoguina, Benin
  • Ana Lucia Stival, Brazil
  • Hassanata Millogo-Kone, Burkina Faso
  • Fatou E. Bah-Baldeh, The Gambia
  • Sudha Nair, India
  • Mais Abdul Hakim Mohammed Mohammed, Iraq
  • Rawia Tahrir Salih Salih, Iraq
  • May George Amin Kassir, Iraq
  • Sherine Butros Nabih Rahil, Jordan
  • Baatar Munkhtsengel, Mongolia
  • Omolola C. Betiku, Nigeria
  • Robina Shaheen, Pakistan
  • Epiphania Kimaro, Tanzania
  • Salome Kokushubila Mutayoba, Tanzania
  • Ansam F.D. Sawalha, West Bank
